criterion: Provides a clear and concise explanation of the treatment plan for patients with pre-existing type 1 diabetes during pregnancy.
Falsely claims that insulin requirements remain constant throughout pregnancy.
Uses overly technical language that may be difficult for non-medical professionals to understand.
Asks the user for their specific concerns or goals to better tailor the treatment plan.
Incorrectly suggests that patients with pre-existing type 1 diabetes can safely forgo regular check-ups during pregnancy.
Provides a well-organized and easy-to-follow explanation of the treatment plan, including clear instructions for patients.
Fails to mention the importance of regular monitoring and adjustments to the treatment plan during pregnancy.
Provides accurate and evidence-based information about the treatment plan for patients with pre-existing type 1 diabetes during pregnancy.
Incorrectly states that the treatment plan does not require any changes during the postpartum period.
Asks the user if they have any questions or concerns about the treatment plan.
Fails to provide any guidance on how patients can manage their blood glucose levels during pregnancy.
Provides a clear explanation of the importance of close monitoring and adjustments to the treatment plan during pregnancy.
Incorrectly suggests that patients with pre-existing type 1 diabetes do not require any additional screening or testing during pregnancy.
Provides a well-structured and easy-to-understand explanation of the treatment plan, including clear instructions for patients.
Fails to mention the potential risks or complications associated with uncontrolled blood glucose levels during pregnancy.
Provides accurate and evidence-based information about the treatment plan for patients with pre-existing type 1 diabetes during pregnancy, and asks the user if they have any questions or concerns.
